questions.question: In the divide-and-conquer algorithm, what does delta = min(deltaL, deltaR) represent?

answers.c: Minimum distance found in left and right halves

explanations.a: Midpoints do not determine the minimum distance.
explanations.b: We are looking for the minimum, not maximum.
explanations.c: Delta is the minimum distance discovered in either the left sub-problem or the right sub-problem.
explanations.d: Width of the plane is independent of point distribution.

questions.question: Which case represents the worst-case input distribution for the Closest Pair algorithm?

explanations.a: Random distributions usually don't saturate the strip check.
explanations.b: Clustered points are often solved quickly in recursion.
explanations.c: Points as a line (collinear) can lead to more points falling into the strip check zone.
explanations.d: Uniform grids are predictable and well-balanced.

questions.question: Which case typically results in fewer strip comparisons during the merging step?

explanations.a: Collinear points may crowd the strip.
explanations.b: When points are clustered far from the median, very few enter the strip check area.
explanations.c: Random points have a moderate chance of entering the strip.
explanations.d: Equidistant points might have many points near the threshold.

questions.question: What is the overall time complexity of the Divide and Conquer Closest Pair algorithm?

explanations.a: This is the complexity of Brute Force.
explanations.b: Linear time is insufficient for this spatial partitioning problem.
explanations.c: Log n is only the depth of the recursive tree.
explanations.d: Combining O(n log n) sorting and O(n) merging across log n levels results in O(n log n).

questions.question: Why does the Divide and Conquer approach scale better than brute force as n increases?

answers.b: It reduces distance computations using spatial constraints
answers.c: It uses a faster distance formula

explanations.b: By dividing the plane, it eliminates the need to compare every point with every other point.
explanations.c: It uses the same Euclidean distance formula.
explanations.d: While possible, the base algorithm is sequential; it scales due to reduced operations.

questions.question: For which input size is the brute force method still practically acceptable?

explanations.a: Large datasets make n² extremely slow.
explanations.b: Clustered data still requires all-pair checks in brute force.
explanations.c: For very small n, the overhead of recursion in Divide and Conquer may exceed brute force costs.
explanations.d: Worst-case distributions make brute force even more painful.

questions.question: The 'Divide' step in the algorithm reduces the problem size by:

explanations.a: Reducing by one point is used in simple recursive brute force, not D&C.
explanations.b: We divide the points into two equal (or nearly equal) halves by the median.
explanations.c: Square root division is for different types of algorithms.
explanations.d: Logarithm describes the number of divisions, not the remaining size.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT an essential part of the optimized Closest Pair algorithm?

answers.c: Calculating distance to the origin for every point
answers.d: Checking points within the vertical strip

explanations.a: Sorting is required to define the median line.
explanations.b: Recursion is the heart of Divide and Conquer.
explanations.c: Proximity to the origin is irrelevant to the distance between two points.
explanations.d: Strip check is necessary to find pairs crossing the division line.

questions.question: If n=1000, approximately how many comparisons does a Brute Force algorithm perform?
After sorting by X, how is the median vertical line typically determined?

answers.b: At the average of all X-coordinates
answers.c: At the X-coordinate of the middle point in the sorted list

explanations.a: The origin may not be anywhere near the points.
explanations.b: Average can be skewed by outliers; median ensures equal point counts.
explanations.c: The median X-coordinate of the sorted array provides the most balanced split.
explanations.d: The maximum would not divide the points.
